storyboard.text: This coin bought a Roman soldier food for a day. Two centuries later, you needed a sack full of them just to buy a loaf of bread. What happened?
storyboard.notes: Split screen comparison: A shiny silver Denarius (Augustus era) vs a dark, bronze-looking coin (Aurelian era). Text overlay: '98% Silver' vs '2% Silver'.

storyboard.text: In the early Empire, the Denarius was the backbone of the economy. It was nearly pure silver, trusted across the known world for trade and commerce.
storyboard.notes: Map of the Roman Empire showing trade routes glowing, with silver coins appearing over major cities.

storyboard.text: But running an empire is expensive. Constant wars, expanding borders, and lavish public games drained the treasury. The Emperors needed more money than they had.
storyboard.notes: Montage of Roman legions marching and construction of massive monuments.

storyboard.text: Instead of cutting costs, they cheated. The mints began adding cheap copper to the mix. Under Nero, it dropped to 90%. By the late 200s, the silver was practically gone.
storyboard.notes: Animation showing a silver coin being diluted with copper. A graphical line chart plummeting from top left to bottom right.

storyboard.text: The public panicked. Merchants raised prices to match the worthless coins. Hyperinflation set in, wiping out savings and destabilizing the very foundations of Rome.
storyboard.notes: A chaotic market scene with people arguing; price numbers floating in the air increasing rapidly.

storyboard.text: The Roman economy collapsed from the inside out. It serves as a timeless warning: a currency is only as strong as the trust behind it.
storyboard.notes: A single, worn-out debased coin spinning slowly and stopping as the light fades.
